Monro, Henry 

        Student United College 1746-[1750]. (Ternar). Bayne bursar, 1746. M.A. 16.4.1750.D.D. 3.1.1781 gratis.

      Born 1730 son of Robert Monro, brother german to John Monro of Kilichoan and Anne Monro.

      Also at Edinburgh University - divinity student.
      Chaplain 77th Highland Regiment 1757 and served in America for 6 years.
      Left army about 1762 and entered Church of England, going to England for ordination 1764-1765.
      Returned to America 1765.
      Held various missionary and preaching offices, being mainly active New York frontier area.
      Loyalist - imprisoned 1776.
      Returned to England 1778
      and in 1783 went to Scotland where he resided until his death.
      Married 3 times and had descendants in America. [Minister, missionary]
      Died Edinburgh 30.5.1801.

raw_data:
Middleton, Peter 

        M.A. 27.2.1752 by examinationand M.D. 27.2.1752 by examination.

        Born Scotland before 1730 son of Mr John Middleton, preacher of the Gospel, Edinburgh. [Preacher]

      Practised New York. Made one of the first dissections of the human body for purposes of medical instruction in America. One of the founders of the St Andrews Society of New York in 1756. President 1767-1770. [Doctor]
      Professor of Physiology and Pathology, King’s College (Columbia University) 1767-1774.
      Governor of King’s College 1773.
      Publications.
      Died 9.1.1781.

      History of St Andrews Society of Philadelphia p428Dictionary of Australian biographyDobson, Scottish settlers vi 82

Leighton, Edward [Francis] Forester 

        Student United College 1891-1892 Chem.; N. Hist.; Physiol. 1892-1893 Chem.; N. Hist. 

        Born 23.5.1874 son of Henry Forester Leighton, barrister, Lahore, Pakistan and Mary Maxwell (of Darvel family). [Lawyer]


        For a time in Natal Mounted Police then in New Zealand.  Served in 1914-1918 War. Started garage near Bristol in 1920’s. Worked in factory in World War II [1940-1945] then drifted about in a boat then lived in the Isle of Wight.
        [Policeman, soldier]
      Died in Isle of Wight County hospital, Ryde 17.9.1959.

      Fettes Coll. Reg.Information from Sir Edward Playfair 3.3.1977

Roger, Charles 
      
        Student United College 1832-1833 Gk. Prov.; Lat. Prov. Lawson bursar, 1832.
      Born 14.4.1819 son of Charles Roger, Dundee, later tobacconist and city librarian, Perth, and Ann Cruickshank.
        Attended Dundee Grammar School (4).
      
      
      Enlisted in Royal Artillery 1835.
      served in Canada.
      Discharged 1842.
      Superintendent Quebec library 1847-1849.
      Worked on Morning Chronicle 1849-1853 and Quebec Gazette.
      Ran his own paper 1854-1855 then returned to Gazette.
      Moved to Port Hope and elsewhere continuing his newspaper ventures. Published on Canadian history. [Soldier, journalist]
      Also at Edinburgh University - medical student 1876 aged 57.
      Cousin of [Charles Roger, United College 1839-1843].
      Probably died 1878.
      
      Dict. Canadian Biog.

Mill, John Stuart 
      Rector, St Andrews University 23.11.1865 - 25.11.1868.
      LL.D. 1.2.1867.
      
      Born 20.5.1806 eldest son of James Mill, London, utilitarian philosopher and Harriet Burrows.
      Educated by his father and privately.
      
      Entered examiner’s office, India House and became Chief in 1856.
      M.P. for Westminster 1865-1868. [Politician]
      Rector, St Andrews University 23.11.1865 - 25.11.1868.
      Philosopher. Publications.
      On Liberty. (London: Longman, Green, 1864)
      Utilitarianism; On Liberty; Representative Government. Introduction by A.D. Lindsay. (London: J.M. Dent & Sons, 1910)
      Inaugural address, delivered to the University of St Andrews, Feb. 1st 1867. (London: Longman, Green, 1867)
      
      
        Died 8.5.1873 in Avignon, France.
      
        DNBFifeshire Jnl. 7.2.1867 p6, 28.2.1867 p3John Stuart Mill in Wikipedia.

raw_data:
Forbes, William Smellie 

        M.D. 26.1.1799 on testimonials signed by Dr. James Walker, Jamaica and Dr. Flint.
        Cousin to Dr Smellie, author of A System of Midwifery.

      Served an apprenticeship, then
      Studied Edinburgh University 1775-1778 and
      Studied London.
      Surgeon Royal Navy 1778-1780.
      Practised Kirkcaldy 1780-1781.
      Surgeon Royal Navy 1781-1783.
      Soon thereafter back in Navy as manager of Naval Hospital, Mole, St Domingo, Dominican Republic until 1795.
      Surgeon General to Naval Hospital at Port Royal, Jamaica 1795-. [Doctor]

Reid, John 

        Student United College 1813-1814 Gk. Jun.; Lat. Jun. 1814-1815 Gk. Prov.; Lat. Prov.; Math. Jun. (Ternar). Gets vacant bursary money, 1813.
      Possibly the man who was born c. 1800 son of John Reid, farmer, Tarbolton and Jean Ronald.

      Also at Edinburgh University 1815-1818 and United Secession divinity hall 1823-1826.
      Licensed by Cupar Secession presbytery 1826.
      Minister Dalry 1829-1833 (suspended and expelled). Cowgate Mission, Edinburgh 1833.
      Joined United Christian Church 1835. Heriot Bridge, Edinburgh 1835-1837. He and congregation joined Original Burgher Synod 1838. Moved with Synod to Church of Scotland 1839.
      Minister Bathgate 1839-1841. Johnstone quoad sacra 1841-1845. Liverpool, Oldham St. 1845-1852.
      Arrived Victoria, Australia May, 1852. Minister Queen St. Melbourne 1852-1853. Esendey 1853-1856. North Melbourne 1857-1858. Scots Sydney 1858-1862 (resigned). Mariners Church, 1862-1867.

        Died Sydney, Australia [Australia] 18.7.1867.

      Church Heritage 3 1984 p201

references: Chalmers, Class list, New College CHA6.14.1-4

raw_data:
M’Donald, Charles Blair 

        Student United College 1872-1873 N. Phil.; Eng. Lit. 1873-1874 N. Phil.; Chem.
      Born 14.11.1856 at Niagara Falls, Ontario, Canada son of Godfrey Macdonald, later of Chicago and Mary Blackwell (grandson of Professor William Macdonald).

      Stockbroker Chicago and New York.
      Became an avid golfer and golf course designer. Designed at Wheaton, Chicago the first 18 hole course in the U.S.A.
      In 1895 became first official amateur champion of the US. Persuaded U.S. golf to accept R & A rules.
      Published Scotland’s Gift: Golf (New York: Scribner, 1928).
      Died at Southampton 21.4.1939.

      
        UYUC400:23.3.1874St Andrews Citizen 19.5.1900J. R. Knerr in Golfiana 1995 p. 9 - 21Golf Jnl. May, 1996Charles B. Macdonald in Wikipedia.

Kantrovich/Kentridge, Morris/Maurice 

        Student United College 1895-1896 Jun. Gk.; Jun. Lat.; Jun. Math. 1896-1897 Gk.; Lat.; Jun. Math.
      Born 3.2.1881 at Vilnius son of Wolf Kantrovich, cantor Sunderland Synagogue and Rose [ ] - grandson did not know her maiden name.

        [First called Morris Kantrovich, afterwards Maurice Kentridge]
        Emigrated to South Africa.
        Studied law and became an attorney first in Natal then in Johannesburg.
        M.P. in South Africa 1914, 1924-1958. [Law student, lawyer, politician] 

        Died in Johannesburg, South Africa [South Africa] 14.12.1964 (apparently wrong date in South African Dictionary of Biography).

      
        Inf. from grandsonMemoirs ‘I recall’ published 1959 in JohannesburgMorris Kentridge in The University of Glasgow Story.

raw_data:
Clinkskill, James 
      
        Student United College 1868-1869 Chem.
      Born 9.5.1853 son of James Clinkskill, engineer and iron founder, Glasgow and Josephine Katrine Marie Michel.
      Attended Madras College, St Andrews.
      
      Entered business in Scotland first in cotton and yarn for 13 years then as a groceryman for 3 years.
      Went to Canada in 1881 to Winnipeg then Battleford where he was active in the community.
      Moved to Saskatoon in 1889 where he established himself as a business man.
      Sat in the Territorial Assembly.
      Mayor of Saskatoon 1900, 1911, and 1912. Active in providing water, sewers and lighting.
      Governor of the University of Saskatchewan.
      Publications.
      A Prairie Memoir: the Life and Times of James Clinkskill 1853-1936, ed. S.D. Hanson (Regina: Canadian Plains Research Center, 2003)
      
      Died 6.8.1936.
      
      
        Various Canadian websites under his nameJames Clinkskill, by Donald Cameron Kerr in Dictionary of Canadian Biography.

Furnell, Michael C[udmore] 
      
        M.D. 20.4.1877 by examination.
      
        Born 1.7.1829 son of Samuel Furnell, Dublin and Maria [ ].
        M.R.C.S.Eng. 18.7.1851 when he was from Pelham Pl., North Brompton.
      Assistant surgeon Indian Medical Service Madras [now Chennai, India] 1855.
      Surgeon General 1885. Retired 1886. [Doctor]
      Discovered chloroform as an anaesthetic in 1847, but did not pursue or publish, although he gave some to Holmes Coote, who actually used it in surgical operations. Principal Madras Medical College 1875-1880. C.I.E. [Companion of the Most Eminent Order of the Indian Empire] 1886.

        Student St Mary’s College 1761-1762. Table bursar, 1762.


        Born 14.9.1742 son of William Wilson, tenant farmer, Carskerdo Farm, Cupar, UK and Alison Landales. [Farmer]

      Also at Glasgow and Edinburgh Universities. [Glasgow University, Edinburgh University]
      Went to America 1765. Tutor College of Philadelphia from 1766. Admitted to bar 1767. Practised Reading then Carlisle. Speculated in land. Moved to Philadelphia 1778. Signatory to United States Declaration of Independence.  Played an important part in establishing federal constitution. [Lawyer]
      Publications.
      Died 21.8.1798.

        Student United College 1843-1844 Gk. 1; Lat. 1.
      
        Baptised 16.2.1821 son of David Tod, painter, St Andrews and Cecilia Bruce. [Artist]
      
      Possibly also at Edinburgh University - 1848-1850 2 - 3 Lit. and
      Studied New College, Edinburgh - divinity student 1853-1854.3.
      cabinet maker by trade. Taught in Jamaica.
      Became a Free Church minister and went to New Zealand in 1859.
      Held charges at Tokomairiro, Oamaru and Dunedin. [Teacher, minister]
      
        Died at Dunedin [New Zealand] 16.8.1903.

      W. Ewing, Annals of the Free Church of Scotland 1843-1900 (1914)G.H. Scholefield, Dictionary of New Zealand biography. 2v. (Wellington, 1940)St Andrews Citizen 3.10.1903

Jennings, John 

        Student United College 1828-1829 Lat. Jun.; Gk. Jun. 1829-1830 Lat. Prov.; Gk. Prov.; Log. 1830-1831 Lat. Prov.; Gk. Prov.; Ethics.
      Born 8.10.1814 son of John Jennings, merchant, Glasgow and [Mary] Tindal.
      Also at Theological Hall of Associate Synod.
      Ordained missionary to Canada 1838.
      Minister United Associate Church, Toronto 1839-1874.
      Member of Senate University of Toronto 1851-1872 and of other educational bodies.
        D.D. New York 1857.
      Publications. Editor Canadian Presbyterian Magazine.
      Died Toronto, Canada 25.2.1876.

        ? baptised 6.2.1828 son of Francis Barnett, Walsall and Sarah [ ].

Black, Alexander 
      
        Student United College 1841-1842 Ethics; Physics; Physiol.; Sens. Phil.
      Said to be born St Andrews - perhaps baptised 17.1.1819 son of David Black, St Andrews and Agnes Jameson.

Ogilvie, Alexander 
      
        Student United College 1837-1838 Lat. Jun.; Gk. Jun.; Math. 1 1838-1839 Gk. Prov.; Lat. Prov.; Math. 2; Chem.

Whitney, William Dwight 
      LL.D. 14.2.1874.

        Born 5.2.1827 son of Joseph Dwight Whitney, businessman and bankerNorthampton, Massachusetts, USA] and Sarah Whitson.

      Studied William College and
      Studied Yale University.
      Professor of Sanskrit, Yale University from 1854 and also of philology from 1869.
      Linguist, Sanskrit scholar and lexicographer. [University professor]
      Publications.

        Died at New Haven, Conn. [Conneticut, U.S.A.] 7.6.1894.

Hunt, James Malcolm 
      
        Student United College 1889-1890 Gk. 1; Lat. 1; Math. 1 1890-1891 Gk. 2; Lat. 2; Math. 2 1891-1892 N. Phil.; Log. 1892-1893 M. Phil.; Eng. Lit.
        Student St Mary’s College 1892-1896. Alexander bursar, 1893. Class prize, 1895.

Richmond, James 

        Student United College 1849-1850 Gk. 1; Lat. 1 1850-1851 Log.; Math. 1. Thomson bursar, 1850.
      Born 1.11.1834 son of John Richmond, Southdean, UK and Catherine Mitchell.

        Sailed for Australia 17.12.1851 and became a leading sheep breeder in New South Wales. Owning several stations and founding one of the most famous stock flocks there. [Landowner]
      Died Kincairney, Perthshire 6.8.1923.

      Census 1851 St AndrewsAustralian Dictionary of BiographyStAUL Correspondence files of the Keeper of Muniments, University of St Andrews JBS/Richmond

Ferguson, Adam (Fergusson)
    Matriculated from St Leonard’s College 1738/39 (29.2.1739).
    B.A. 1741, minus potens.
    M.A. 4.5.1742, minus potens.
    Attended mathematics classes 1739 – 41.
    Admitted Civis bibliothecae October 1741.
    Born 20.6.1723 son of Adam Ferguson, minister at Logierait and Mary Gordon.

    Chaplain of Black Watch at battle of Fontenoy
    Librarian Advocate’s Library 1757.

    Professor of Moral Philosophy Edinburgh University 1764 – 85.
    Visited Voltaire at Ferney.
     Secretary to British Commisioners at Philadelphia 1778.
    Professor of Mathematics, Edinburgh University 1785 – , in effect as a pension.
    Publications.
    Died at St Andrews 22.2.1816.

Carnegie, James (Carnegy)
    Matriculated from St Leonard’s College 1703/04 (23.2.1704).

Orme, Alexander
    Matriculated from St Leonard’s College 1691/92 (30.3.1692).
    M.A. and M.D. 10.12.1733 on testimonials signed by George Cheyne M.D. and John Middleton M.D., Bath 25.9.1733. At this time he was practicing in the East Indies (Quaestor’s account – granted) Probably the Alexander Orme who is said to have gone to India as an adventurer about 1686 ( a date which must therefore be wrong).
     Surgeon at Angenjo 1707 or earlier.
     Chief surgeon c. 1721. Removed 1728.
     Senior merchant and second in Council at Angenjo 1721.
     At Calcutta 1731.
     Died Calcutta 19.4.1736.
    Father of Robert Orme, the historian.
    
      Crawford, IMS B18

Hay, George
    Matriculated from St Leonard’s College semi class 1704/05 (16.2.1705).
    ‘Filius primogenitus vicecomitis de Dupplin’.
    Born 23.6.1689 eldest son of Thomas Hay, Viscount Dupplin and later Earl of Kinnoull and Margaret Drummond.
